[[Stanford University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) }} '''Maya Lakshmi Harris''' (born January 30, 1967) is an American [[lawyer]], public policy advocate, and television commentator. She is a political analyst for [[MSNBC]]{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/06/20/playbook-juice-june-20-239744 |work=[[Politico]]|title=Tuesday's Juice|date=June 20, 2017 |accessdate=21 November 2017}} and in 2015 was appointed as one of three senior policy advisors to lead the development of an agenda for [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign]].{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/04/clinton-names-top-three-wonks-for-campaign-116975.html|title=Hillary Clinton names top three wonks for campaign |first=David |last=Nather |date=April 14, 2015 |newspaper=[[Politico]]}} She was formerly a senior fellow at the [[Center for American Progress]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/third-ranking-official-at-justice-department-to-step-down/2014/09/03/747061a0-3378-11e4-a723-fa3895a25d02_story.html |title=Tony West, third-ranking official at Justice Department, to step down |first=Sari |last=Horwitz |date=September 3, 2014 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}} From 2008 until she took her current position, she was Vice President for Democracy, Rights and Justice at the [[Ford Foundation]]. Prior to joining the Ford Foundation, she served as the Executive Director of the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) of Northern California.{{cite web|url=http://www.aclunc.org/about/senior_staff/maya_harris,_aclu-nc_executive_director.shtml|title=Maya Harris, ACLU-NC Executive Director|publisher=ACLU|accessdate=21 January 2010}}{{cite book|last=Ifill|first=Gwen|title=The Breakthrough: Politics and Race in the Age of Obama|year=2009|publisher=Anchor Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0-7679-2890-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=DIBJPbTQygsC&pg=PA208 |edition=1st|authorlink=Gwen Ifill|page=208}} Before joining the ACLU, the former law school dean (Lincoln Law School of San Jose) was a Senior Associate at [[PolicyLink]]. She has authored two publications which include a report highlighting community-centered policing practices nationwide and an advocacy manual for police reform. She most recently served as campaign chairwoman for her sister [[Kamala Harris]]'s [[Kamala_Harris_2020_presidential_campaign|2020 campaign for president]], until the campaign's suspension on December 3rd, 2019. ==Early life and education== Born in [[Champaign-Urbana, Illinois]], Harris grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area and Montreal, Quebec. She is the daughter of [[Shyamala Gopalan|Shyamala Gopalan Harris]] (1938–2009), a breast cancer researcher who emigrated from [[Chennai]], [[India]], in 1960{{cite web |url=http://www.desiclub.com/community/culture/culture_article.cfm?id=467 |title=The New Face of Politics… An Interview with Kamala Harris |publisher=DesiClub |accessdate=February 2, 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211152014/http://www.desiclub.com/community/culture/culture_article.cfm?id=467 |archivedate=December 11, 2010 }} and Donald Harris, a Jamaican [[Stanford University]] economics professor.{{cite news|title=PM Golding congratulates Kamala Harris - daughter of Jamaican - on appointment as California's First Woman Attorney General |publisher=Jamaica Information Service |date=December 2, 2010 |url=https://jis.gov.jm/pm-golding-congratulates-kamala-harris-daughter-of-jamaican-on-appointment-as-californias-first-woman-attorney-general-2/ |accessdate=2019-01-21 |url-status=live |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115023007/http://www.jis.gov.jm/news/opm-news/26176-officePM-pm-golding-congratulates-kamala-harris-daughter-of-jamaican-on-appoint |archivedate=January 15, 2012 }} Her maternal grandfather, [[P.V. Gopalan]] was a career civil servant with federal [[Government of India]].{{cite news|title=Obituary: Dr. Shyamala G. Harris|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?pid=125330757|accessdate=June 11, 2017|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=March 22, 2009}} She and her older sister, [[Kamala Harris|Kamala]], were raised with beliefs from Baptist and Hindu faiths.{{cite news|last1=Owens|first1=Donna M.|title=California Attorney General Kamala Harris Plans to be America's Next Black Female Senator|url=http://www.essence.com/2016/01/13/california-attorney-general-kamala-harris-americas-next-black-female-senator|accessdate=June 11, 2017|work=[[Essence (magazine)|Essence]]|date=January 13, 2016}} At the age of 8, with her sister, she persuaded the management of their apartment building to open an unused courtyard as a place for children to play.{{cite news|last=Dzieza|first=Josh|title=Legal Power Sisters Credit Mom|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/03/10/mother-knows-best-the-kamala-sisters-on-how-mommy-led-them-to-law.html|newspaper=The Daily Beast|date=March 10, 2012}} She received her Bachelor of Arts degree from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1989. That year, she enrolled in [[Stanford Law School]]. While at Stanford, she was active with the East Palo Alto Community Law Project, serving as Co-Coordinator of the Domestic Violence Clinic and Co-Chair of the Student Steering Committee.{{cite journal|title=Officially Speaking|journal=Student Lawyer|date=December 1998|volume=27|issue=2|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LHI4AQAAIAAJ |page=16 |publisher=Law Student Division, American Bar Association}} ==Career== Following law school, Harris served as a law clerk for United States District Court Judge [[James Ware (judge)|James Ware]] in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California|Northern District of California]]. In 1994 Harris joined the San Francisco law firm of Jackson Tufts Cole & Black, LLP, working in civil and criminal litigation. In 1997 the Young Lawyers Division of the [[National Bar Association]] honored her with the Junius W. Williams Young Lawyer of the Year Award. The following year, she was named one of the Top 20 Up and Coming Lawyers Under 40 by the ''[[San Francisco Daily Journal]]''.Equal Justice Society; Protecting Equally: Dismantling the Intent Doctrine & Healing Racial Wounds, Maya Harris Harris served as a law professor at the [[University of San Francisco School of Law]]. She also taught contract law at [[New College of California School of Law]] and [[Lincoln Law School of San Jose]]. ===Advocacy=== Harris was a Senior Associate at [[PolicyLink]], a national research and action institute dedicated to advancing economic and social equity. In that capacity, she organized conferences around police-community relations{{cite news|last=Hafertepen|first=Eric|title=News: We Have to Talk About This|url=http://www.citybeat.com/cincinnati/article-5988-news_we_have_to_talk_about_this.html|newspaper=CityBeat|date=July 5, 2001}} and advocated for police reform,{{cite news|last=Prendergast|first=Jane|title=Researchers urge police reforms|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/enquirer/access/1841018521.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+02%2C+2001&author=Jane+Prendergast&pub=Cincinnati+Enquirer&desc=Researchers+urge+police+reforms&pqatl=google|newspaper=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=June 2, 2001}} authoring ''Organized for Change: The Activist's Guide to Police Reform''.{{cite web|title=PolicyLink Guide Offers Innovative Strategies for Police Reform Advocates|url=http://www.policylink.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=lkIXLbMNJrE&b=5156723&ct=6994489|publisher=PolicyLink|date=April 8, 2004|access-date=January 24, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713190719/http://www.policylink.org/site/apps/nlnet/content2.aspx?c=lkIXLbMNJrE&b=5156723&ct=6994489|archive-date=July 13, 2010|url-status=dead}} Harris served as Executive Director of the Northern California [[American Civil Liberties Union]]. In her role as the head of the largest affiliate office of the ACLU, Harris directed and coordinated litigation, media relations, lobbying, and grassroots organizing work. "The Project's priorities are eliminating racial disparities in the criminal justice system and achieving [[educational equity]] in California public schools." In 2003, Harris was the Northern California director for No on 54, the campaign to defeat [[California Proposition 54 (2003)|Proposition 54]], which sought to end affirmative action in the state.{{cite news|title=Prop. 54 soundly beaten: The tide turned when foes of the ballot measure shifted gears from bias to health care|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SB&p_theme=sb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FE138315C60A2C3&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=The Sacramento Bee|date=October 8, 2003}} Harris authored the essay "Fostering Accountable Community-Centered Policing", which appeared in the 2006 book ''[[The Covenant with Black America]]''.{{cite book|title=The Covenant with Black America|year=2006|publisher=Third World Press|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-88378-277-4|pages=[https://archive.org/details/covenantwithblac00chic/page/71 71–95]|edition=1st|chapter=Fostering Accountable Community-Centered Policing|chapter-url-access=registration|chapter-url=https://archive.org/details/covenantwithblac00chic/page/71}} In 2012 Harris was Vice President for Democracy, Rights and Justice at the [[Ford Foundation]]. One of the issues she addresses through her position is the problem of [[child marriage|child brides]]. ==Personal life== Harris has been married to [[Tony West (attorney)|Tony West]] since July 1998. Maya and Tony were both in the class of 1992 at Stanford Law School.{{cite news|last=Driscoll|first=Sharon|title=Tony and Maya: Partners in Public Service|url=https://law.stanford.edu/stanford-lawyer/articles/tony-and-maya-partners-in-public-service/|newspaper=Stanford Lawyer|date=May 17, 2010 |access-date=February 25, 2019}} Maya and Tony became friends, but did not begin a relationship until after graduation.{{cite news|last1=Horwitz|first1=Sari|title=Justice Dept. lawyer Tony West to take over as acting associate attorney general|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/justice-dept-lawyer-tony-west-to-take-over-as-acting-associate-attorney-general/2012/02/24/gIQAqyBOeR_story.html|accessdate=June 11, 2017|work=Washington Post|date=February 27, 2012}} Her daughter, Meena Harris, graduated from Stanford in 2006 and from Harvard Law School in 2012.{{Cite
